2007-03-06.snippet: A380 ARRIVING An A380 airliner with about 500 passengers aboard will arrive at Kennedy International Airport from Frankfurt around noon on March 19 in a test flight to demonstrate what its operator, Lufthansa, and its manufacturer, Airbus, call th...
2007-03-06.lead_paragraph: A380 ARRIVING An A380 airliner with about 500 passengers aboard will arrive at Kennedy International Airport from Frankfurt around noon on March 19 in a test flight to demonstrate what its operator, Lufthansa, and its manufacturer, Airbus, call the A380’s “operational maturity.” It will mark the first time the so-called super-jumbo airliner has been flown overseas with a full passenger load and meal service. Most of the passengers will be Airbus and Lufthansa employees, though some reporters and photographers will also be aboard. Lufthansa has ordered 15 A380s and expects its first delivery in summer 2009. Meanwhile, another Airbus A380 — this one without passengers and operated by a crew from the Australian airline Qantas — is expected to arrive on the same day and at about the same time at Los Angeles International Airport, according to a joint statement by Airbus, the airport, the Los Angeles mayor’s office and Qantas. That flight will depart from Airbus headquarters in Toulouse, France, where the A380 program has had unexpected manufacturing delays. Los Angeles International has long lagged in making the extensive renovations to terminal gates and taxiways to accommodate the double-decker airliner, and is still some time away from doing so. The A380 will park on a ramp at Los Angeles for publicity and ground-based tests. Airbus and some airlines with A380 orders have criticized Los Angeles International for falling behind on the renovations. The airport, which is competing with San Francisco as a major Pacific overseas gateway, recently began a $723.5 million modernization of its international terminal that will include at least two gates that can accommodate the A380. Qantas has ordered 20 A380s and expects its first delivery in summer 2008.

2007-03-13.snippet: FLYERTALK.COM SOLD FlyerTalk.com, the Web site with scores of vibrant forums on frequent-flier programs, loyalty points and travel, has been sold to Internet Brands by Randy Petersen, who founded the site almost nine years ago. Mr. Petersen will c...
2007-03-13.lead_paragraph: FLYERTALK.COM SOLD FlyerTalk.com, the Web site with scores of vibrant forums on frequent-flier programs, loyalty points and travel, has been sold to Internet Brands by Randy Petersen, who founded the site almost nine years ago. Mr. Petersen will continue as a consultant for four years. In e-mail messages to members and to site moderators, Mr. Petersen said he decided to sell only after “plenty of sleepless nights.” Other travel companies that had expressed interest, he said, included American Express, Expedia, Travelocity and Condé Nast Interactive. Internet Brands operates e-commerce sites for cars, real estate, mortgages and travel. Mr. Petersen said he chose Internet Brands, which was not the highest bidder, because “they weren’t interested in making any changes” to FlyerTalk.com.

2007-03-27.snippet: TRAVEL COST MORE IN 2006 Average one-way domestic air fares paid by corporations, which dropped to a six-year low in 2005, rose last year to $231, the American Express Business Travel Monitor reported. Average one-way international fares continued...
2007-03-27.lead_paragraph: TRAVEL COST MORE IN 2006 Average one-way domestic air fares paid by corporations, which dropped to a six-year low in 2005, rose last year to $231, the American Express Business Travel Monitor reported. Average one-way international fares continued a four-year climb, to $1,707, and average international daily hotel rates rose for the fifth consecutive year, to $230. Average daily car rental rates crept up again, to $69. Corporate pressure on business travelers to comply with booking policies held down the rate of increases, said Mike Streit, vice president of American Express Business Travel Advisory Services. The average air fare rates were calculated from hundreds of domestic and international routes negotiated for corporate clients by American Express, from discount coach to first class. The average rate for car rentals includes fuel, taxes and other charges. Among domestic hotels, average nightly rates rose most sharply in the cheapest niche, the budget category, to $179 in the fourth quarter of 2006 from $150 in the comparable 2005 quarter.
